nexttext:
\noindent As a caveat we must note that in a few cases of X-ray binaries it has been seen that the ouflowing gases have velocities much less than the escape velocity at that radius \citep{2006Natur.441..953M}. 

Secondly, the launch radius can also be calculated by assuming that the WA originates at the base of the broad line region (BLR). A recent study by \citet{2011A&A...525L...8C} pointed out that the broad line region (BLR) in an AGN could originate as clouds uplifted from the outer parts of the accretion disk where the temperature is $\sim 1000$ K. Beyond the dust sublimation radius the radiation pressure on the dusty clouds can sustain the radiatively driven outflows, while below this radius the dust grains sublimate and there is not enough radiative push on the clouds and they fall back on the disk due to gravity. \citet{2015ARA&A..53..365N} in a recent review has discussed how the dust sublimation radius can give us an estimate of the inner margins of the BLR. \citet{1987ApJ...320..537B} had shown that for AGN dust heated by the central luminous source, a dust sublimation radius can be defined as

\noindent where $L_{46}$ is the bolometric luminosity of the AGN in units of $10^{46}{\rm \,erg \,s^{-1}}$ and $T_{\rm sub}$ is the dust sublimation temperature (in K), and $f(\theta)$ is an angular dependent term which is 1 for an isotropic source. Hence, we assume $f(\theta)=1$ for simplicity. In a wind driven by radiation pressure on dusty clouds ${r_{\rm dust}}$ is therefore an order-of-magnitude estimate of the launch radius. In Figure \ref{fig:rdust}, left panel we show how the ${r_{\rm dust}}$ compares with the virial estimates of ${r_{\rm min}}$ in our sample. { Figure \ref{fig:rmin-by-rdust} shows how the two distance estimates ${r_{\rm min}}$ and ${r_{\rm dust}}$ compare for each 25 individual WA.}


A further estimate of the warm absorbing cloud location can be obtained using the geometrical definition of ``cloud". We assume that its thickness $\Delta r$, does not exceed its distance from the ionising source \citep{2001ApJ...561..684K,2005A&A...431..111B}. As ${ N_{\rm H}}=n_{\rm H} V_f \Delta r$, imposing $\Delta r=r$ yields an upper limit on the cloud launching radius
prevtext:
\noindent As a caveat we must note that in a few cases of X-ray binaries it has been seen that the ouflowing gases have velocities much less than the escape velocity at that radius \citep{2006Natur.441..953M}. 

Secondly, the launch radius can also be calculated by assuming that the WA originates at the base of the broad line region (BLR). A recent study by \citet{2011A&A...525L...8C} pointed out that the broad line region (BLR) in an AGN could originate as clouds uplifted from the outer parts of the accretion disk where the temperature is $\sim 1000$ K. Beyond the dust sublimation radius the radiation pressure on the dusty clouds can sustain the radiatively driven outflows, while below this radius the dust grains sublimate and there is not enough radiative push on the clouds and they fall back on the disk due to gravity. \citet{2015ARA&A..53..365N} in a recent review has discussed how the dust sublimation radius can give us an estimate of the inner margins of the BLR. \citet{1987ApJ...320..537B} had shown that for AGN dust heated by the central luminous source, a dust sublimation radius can be defined as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{r_{\rm dust}}=R_{\rm Sub,graphite}\sim 0.5*L^{0.5}_{46}(1800/T_{\rm sub})^{2.%
6}f(\theta)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>dust</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mi>Sub</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>graphite</mi></mrow></msub><mo>∼</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mo>*</mo><msubsup><mi>L</mi><mn>46</mn><mn>0.5</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1800</mn><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>T</mi><mi>sub</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2.6</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent where $V_f$ is the volume filling factor of the cloud (see Section \ref{subsec:vol} for details), ${L_{\rm ion}}$ is the ionising luminosity, $\xi$ is the ionisation parameter, ${ N_{\rm H}}$ is the column density and $n_{\rm H}$ is the hydrogen density of the cloud. This distance estimate follows from a geometrical argument, which may not always hold. ${r_{\rm max}}$ calculated using Equation \ref{equ:rmax} yields estimates as large as a few ${\,{\rm {Mpc}}}$ (modulo $V_f$). We discuss the interpretation  of these results in Sec. \ref{subsec:rmax}.


We scale all the distances with the Schwarzschild radius of the super massive blackhole (SMBH),

Hence, we assume $f(\theta)=1$ for simplicity. In a wind driven by radiation pressure on dusty clouds ${r_{\rm dust}}$ is therefore an order-of-magnitude estimate of the launch radius. In Figure \ref{fig:rdust}, left panel we show how the ${r_{\rm dust}}$ compares with the virial estimates of ${r_{\rm min}}$ in our sample. { Figure \ref{fig:rmin-by-rdust} shows how the two distance estimates ${r_{\rm min}}$ and ${r_{\rm dust}}$ compare for each 25 individual WA.}

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="r_{\rm max}=\frac{L_{\rm ion}V_{f}}{\xi{N_{\rm H}}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>r</mi><mi>max</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>ion</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\noindent where $V_f$ is the volume filling factor of the cloud (see Section \ref{subsec:vol} for details), ${L_{\rm ion}}$ is the ionising luminosity, $\xi$ is the ionisation parameter, ${ N_{\rm H}}$ is the column density and $n_{\rm H}$ is the hydrogen density of the cloud. This distance estimate follows from a geometrical argument, which may not always hold. ${r_{\rm max}}$ calculated using Equation \ref{equ:rmax} yields estimates as large as a few ${\,{\rm {Mpc}}}$ (modulo $V_f$). nexttext:
\noindent where $m_p$ and ${ N_{\rm H}}$ denote the mass of proton and the column density of the WA clouds respectively. $f(\delta,\phi)$ is a factor which depends on the angle between the line of sight to the central source and the accretion disc plane, $\delta$, and the angle formed by the wind with the accretion disc, $\phi$. We have assumed a value $f(\delta,\phi)\sim 1.5$ \citep{2007ApJ...659.1022K,2013MNRAS.430.1102T}. The ratio of the proton to electron abundance ($n_{\rm H}/n_{\rm e}$) is expressed as $\mu$ and we have assumed a Solar value of $1/1.4$. { We compared these mass outflow estimates with a few other different methods in Appendix \ref{appendix} and found that they are similar to within an order of magnitude.}



 In our study, the mass outflow rate is scaled with the Eddington mass accretion rate, which is given by:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{M}_{\rm out\,(max/min)}=\mu\,\pi\,m_{p}\,{N_{\rm H}}\,{v_{\rm out}}\,r_{%
\rm(max/min)}\,f(\delta,\phi)," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>out</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>max</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>min</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>μ</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>π</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>out</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>r</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>max</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>min</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>δ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
\noindent where $m_p$ and ${ N_{\rm H}}$ denote the mass of proton and the column density of the WA clouds respectively. $f(\delta,\phi)$ is a factor which depends on the angle between the line of sight to the central source and the accretion disc plane, $\delta$, and the angle formed by the wind with the accretion disc, $\phi$. We have assumed a value $f(\delta,\phi)\sim 1.5$ \citep{2007ApJ...659.1022K,2013MNRAS.430.1102T}. The ratio of the proton to electron abundance ($n_{\rm H}/n_{\rm e}$) is expressed as $\mu$ and we have assumed a Solar value of $1/1.4$. { We compared these mass outflow estimates with a few other different methods in Appendix \ref{appendix} and found that they are similar to within an order of magnitude.}



 In our study, the mass outflow rate is scaled with the Eddington mass accretion rate, which is given by:
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{M}_{\rm Edd}=\frac{L_{\rm Edd}}{\eta c^{2}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>Edd</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>Edd</mi></msub><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\dot{E}_{\rm K}}=L_{\rm KE}=\frac{1}{2}\dot{M}_{\rm out}\,{v_{\rm out}}^{2}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>KE</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>out</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mmultiscripts><mi>v</mi><mi>out</mi><none/><none/><mn>2</mn></mmultiscripts></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent and the radiation momentum rate is given by,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{P}_{\rm out}=\dot{M}_{\rm out}\,{v_{\rm out}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>P</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>out</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>out</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>out</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent where ${L_{\rm ion}}$ is the ionising luminosity of the source measured in the range 1-1000 Ryd. The incident ionising photons interact with the warm absorber clouds and get absorbed or scattered whereby they transfer their momentum to the cloud. The amount of absorption depends on the optical depth offered by the clouds to the impinging photons. The momentum tranferred to the cloud due to the absorption of photons is given by
prevtext: \noindent and the radiation momentum rate is given by,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{P}_{\rm rad}=\frac{{L_{\rm ion}}}{c}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>P</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>rad</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>L</mi><mi>ion</mi></msub><mi>c</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: \noindent where ${L_{\rm ion}}$ is the ionising luminosity of the source measured in the range 1-1000 Ryd. The incident ionising photons interact with the warm absorber clouds and get absorbed or scattered whereby they transfer their momentum to the cloud. The amount of absorption depends on the optical depth offered by the clouds to the impinging photons. The momentum tranferred to the cloud due to the absorption of photons is given by
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\dot{P}_{\rm abs,Tot}}=\frac{{L_{\rm abs,Tot}}}{c}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>P</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mrow><mi>abs</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Tot</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>L</mi><mrow><mi>abs</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>Tot</mi></mrow></msub><mi>c</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent where the scattered momentum is given by,

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="V_{f}\sim\frac{({L_{\rm abs}}+{L_{\rm ion}}(1-e^{-\tau_{\rm T}}))\xi}{1.23m_{p%

nexttext: \noindent where $C_{\rm g}$ is the global covering factor, typically assumed to be $\sim 0.5$. Another estimate of mass outflow rate can be obtained following \citet{2005A&A...431..111B} where the authors assume an inverse square mass density profile of the warm absorber clouds ($n(r) \propto 1/r^2$), and the mass outflow rate in such a scenario is given by,
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\dot{M}_{\rm out}}=4\,\pi\,r\,{N_{\rm H}}\,\mu\,m_{\rm p}\,C_{\rm g}\,{v_{\rm
out%
}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>M</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>out</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mn>4</mn></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>π</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi>μ</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mi>C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></msub></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>out</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: \noindent where $C_{\rm g}$ is the global covering factor, typically assumed to be $\sim 0.5$.
